bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 15, 1900

div1.p: Lazear reports that his wife has been hospitalized.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 15, 1900
div1.p:
I was glad
to learn that you were
going to Annisquam
earlier than at first
planned. It was better
for Mabel to go to the
hospital early and I
hope now that she
will not have long
to wait. Houston
may disturb you at
night but I hope you
will manage to get
plenty of sleep.

A good many of the
soldiers are leaving
Cuba but our board
will probably be kept
here for some time.

It is not likely that
all the troops will
go as Uncle Sam will
want to hold the
sea defenses to the task.
Therefore our wants will
be provided for from
the commissary. We
rely on the beef and provisions
which the government
brings here. Cuban fare
would not be agreable.
The soldiers are very glad to go and
the officers are anxious for service
in China.

The weather contains fairly good.
The nights are cool. There is a
storm every afternoon. This is the
regular thing during the rainy
season.

I shall of course feel pretty anxious
until I hear that Mabel is safely
over her trouble. I hope that
arrangements are made so that
I shall be informed promptly
by cable. Address simply
Dr. Lazear, Columbia Barracks, Cuba.
Give my love to dear little Houston
